_If people agree, then I’ll start doing it. I’d like to see the category be a full-fledged research bibliography._

George, please do start it yourself. The WIKI is entirely self-run. There is no "editorial panel" or such a thing (although Paul is sort of the wiki-Godfather). It thrives only on individual contributions. The more you "cross-link" in your posts, the more likely other authors will likely be to catch the interest…

May I suggest the following categories:

- **Creationists** (in deference to Nick Shinn)  
Those who conjure up type designs out of nothing, citing no precedents and recognizing no influences;
- **Intelligent Designers**  
Those who posit that typeface design is far too complex a process to have happened accidentally, so _somebody_ must have been responsible for the design (although _precisely_ who may remain a matter of theological, philosophical or epistemological debate); and
- **Evolutionists**  
Those who acknowledge the design contributions of type designers who came before them, and _adapt_ those designs so that they live on in a new (digital) format (Paul Hunt's Bezier Wranglers?)

_Then_, we could get the courts involved, and let them determine which approach is the superior one...

Well, if no one agrees about the bibliographic thing then I'll shut up about it. But I will make sure there's at least a full name for every author.

If people agree, then I'll start doing it. I'd like to see the category be a full-fledged research bibliography.

_I think the “Books” category should be more bibliographic._

george, the great thing about the wiki is that if you feel you can improve upon it, you can!

In this particular instance, I wanted to get others' opinions before i made any changes.

I think the question should be how the subcategories are handled. Obviously there would be a tremendous amount of duplication if there are separate sub-lists. If there were a method of tagging each entry with appropriate subcategories that would be preferable. I'm assuming there is / would be a way of searching so the user could make their own list, and allow for overlap in the search. I've been putting things in and haven't really used it for that yet.

And there's the issue of who is using it. I find my students use Wiki a lot, but my colleagues don't. So I'm not in favor of anything that makes it harder for students to find things, but in favor of anything that makes it more informative.

I also think the list should include everyone involved in type including authors, scholars, librarians, and archivists: Nicolette Gray, Robin Kinross, H.D.L. Vervliet, etc.

I think the "Books" category should be more bibliographic.

George

If anything, you should consider the Typowiki as a growing resource for all things typographic and type related, and as a resource it should be accessible and understandable to visitors.

Personally, I see no need for many sub-classifications, since for the most part, people involved with type are often multi-disciplined. How many time would you enter Hermann Zapf? Type designer, type educator, typographer, calligrapher, graphic designer (he has done it), husband, etc.?

What I do see lacking in our "Designers" section are people who have made significant contributions to the futherment of type in aesthetics, education, scholarly-research, marketing, etc., yet have never designed an actual typeface.

The majority of individuals listed in the "Designers" category are actual type designers, a few punchcutters, and a scattering of "typophiles" such as [Roger Black](http://web.archive.org/web/20130903083945/http:/www.fontbureau.com/people/RogerBlack), who I don't recall ever actually designed a typeface despite his incredible contribution to the world of type.

Likewise, a person like Aaron Burns (I "Typowikied" him but can't find it) should be listed, but not under "Designers."

So if anything, I see two basic and clear catergories:

- **Type Designers**  
Individuals who have a typeface(s) attributed to their design, along with any other of their type related activities.

and

- **Typophiles** (for lack of a better all inclusive definition)  
Which is for individuals who have NOT actually designed a typeface, but have made significant contributions to the world of type.

Just my humble opinion.

Getting too specific about this is going to be a horrror show, no offense. This task is like trying to come up with a genre for a band between a few hundred different people. Nobody will agree on the same one. I think it's better to just leave it at one general section.
